author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Christine Hauser
title: Murderer Pardoned by Kentucky’s Former Governor Is Sentenced Again
description: Patrick Baker’s family hosted a fund-raiser for the former governor, Matt Bevin, before he was pardoned in 2019. He was convicted by a federal jury this summer and sentenced to 42 years in prison.
content: A Kentucky man who was pardoned by the state’s former governor in 2019 was sentenced to 42 years in prison this week on federal charges for the same murder, the Justice Department said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin and Amy Chang Chien
title: ‘We Are Taiwanese’: China’s Growing Menace Hardens Island’s Identity
description: More than ever, Taiwan defines itself by its democratic values. Beijing’s military and diplomatic threats only reinforce the island’s separateness.
content: CHIAYI, Taiwan — When Li Yuan-hsin, a 36-year-old high school teacher, travels abroad, people often assume she is Chinese.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Hanage
title: After Omicron, This Pandemic Will Be Different
description: Future surges will be less likely to make us seriously ill.
content: Omicron is really good at infecting people and doing it fast. So fast, in fact, that by the time you read this, chances are that cases have already reached a peak in your neighborhood.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Riders Flowing to the Subway, or Trickling In
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, January 19, 2022.
content: “If this keeps up, people are going to lose a good cobbler, and that’s a pity for the city.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A State Budget With an Unexpected Twist: No Red Ink
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul announced a $216.3 billion spending plan as officials projected balanced state budgets through 2027.
content: Good morning. We’ll look at Gov. Kathy Hochul’s state budget, which came with an unexpected twist. We’ll also look at who is not running for governor, and who is riding the subways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Jeremy Irons Is Transported by Renzo Piano and a Dog Named Smudge
description: The star of the new Netflix movie ‘Munich — The Edge of War’ discusses his first Broadway gig and the connection between Irish fiddling and jazz.
content: “Am I talking too much?” Jeremy Irons asked. “I tend to get a bit loquacious.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: What Have You Dreamed About Lately?
description: Night visions, two years in.
content: Welcome. I keep forgetting how I know things. With so much of life transpiring through screens — Zoom calls, group texts, long articles saved to read later, Netflix series half-paid-attention-to while scrolling through Instagram — I’ll find myself recalling a fact or a story, unable to identify the source of the information. Did this dimly recollected tale of, say, getting stranded in a blizzard come from a friend or colleague? Did I hear about it on a podcast? Is it a vignette from a movie I watched part of and then abandoned? How do I know what I know? What is fact and what is fiction?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: Survey of Americans Who Attempted Suicide Finds Many Aren’t Getting Care
description: The number of people who try suicide has risen steadily in the U.S. But despite gains in health coverage, nearly half are not getting mental health treatment.
content: Suicide attempts in the United States showed a “substantial and alarming increase” over the last decade, but one number remained the same, a new study has found: Year in and year out, about 40 percent of people who had recently tried suicide said they were not receiving mental health services.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: Ghislaine Maxwell’s Bid for a New Trial Faces a Major Hurdle
description: The rule that a trial judge cannot ask what happened in the jury room could block an attempt by Ms. Maxwell’s lawyers to overturn the verdict.
content: The judge was questioning potential jurors for the Ghislaine Maxwell sex-trafficking trial when she asked a 35-year-old Manhattan man, identified as Juror 50, whether he had any doubt about his ability to be fair to both sides.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Dudding
title: Voting Rights, Omicron, André Leon Talley: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Loos
title: At 83, Arne Glimcher Indulges His Inner Curator
description: The founder and chairman of Pace Gallery is opening a new space in TriBeCa, his own “little modern museum.” Retirement? That’s not in the cards.
content: At 83, Arne Glimcher has already had unusual longevity as a top art dealer, with more than six decades in the business. But he is still expanding his reach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley and Andrew E. Kramer
title: As U.S. and Russia Prepare to Talk, Blinken Presents Hard Line
description: The U.S. secretary of state met with Ukraine’s president and said he would not present a written diplomatic proposal to Russia when he meets with his Russian counterpart on Friday.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken on Wednesday said that when he meets with his Russian counterpart on Friday, he would not provide the written response to Russia’s demands on Eastern European security that the Kremlin says it expects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: How to Beat Letter Boxed at Its Own Game
description: A few of our top solvers offer their best tips and tricks for becoming a “2-solver.”
content: A confession: I am not good at The New York Times’s Letter Boxed game. No, let me correct that. I stink at our Letter Boxed game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Gandel
title: How 5G Clashed With an Aviation Device Invented in the 1920s
description: The potential for interference between 5G signals and the radio altimeters long used by pilots has divided the telecom and aviation industries.
content: A technological innovation that helped pilots fly fighter jets during World War II is now at the heart of the dispute between airlines and AT&T and Verizon over 5G, an innovative service meant to speed up mobile devices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Three Police Officers Charged in Fatal Shooting of Child Outside Football Game
description: The officers opened fire after two teenagers began shooting outside a high school stadium in a Philadelphia suburb.
content: Three Pennsylvania police officers have been charged with manslaughter in the fatal shooting of an 8-year-old girl outside a high school football game in August during which they fired a barrage of bullets after two teenagers began shooting, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: Review: A Skilled Ballet Leader Creates a Messy ‘Raymonda’
description: Tamara Rojo, San Francisco Ballet’s incoming artistic director, has half updated the 19th-century work for English National Ballet.
content: LONDON — Esteemed ballerina. Experienced artistic director. Skilled fund-raiser. In Tamara Rojo, who was announced last week as San Francisco Ballet’s next leader, American dance has tapped a woman of many talents. Still, the San Francisco company may want to hold off on adding choreography to her list of duties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles V. Bagli
title: ‘He Killed Her in Westchester’: Report Details N.Y. Durst Investigation
description: Nearly four decades after Kathie McCormack Durst disappeared, prosecutors say they are confident she was killed by her husband, Robert Durst.
content: The many mysteries surrounding Robert A. Durst, the onetime real estate scion who died last week while in custody following his murder conviction in California, started with his first wife, who vanished from a cottage in a small town in Westchester County, New York, in 1982.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: What Eric Adams’s Hires Say About Him: Loyalty Comes First
description: Mr. Adams, who has brought a number of close allies into City Hall, says he is subject to greater scrutiny over hiring than his predecessors faced.
content: It was only his second week as mayor of New York City, and Eric Adams was fielding question after question about ethical concerns over his recent appointments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Exclusive: Lina Khan Is (Still) Bursting Big Tech’s Bubble
description: The FTC Chair’s exclusive conversation with Kara Swisher and Andrew Ross Sorkin.
content: Yesterday, the Federal Trade Commission and the Department of Justice announced they would work to rewrite merger rules in an approach that would clamp down on big tech deals that have allowed companies like Amazon, Google and Facebook to expand their tentacles across industries and across more areas of our lives. Today, Lina Khan sat down with Kara Swisher and DealBook’s editor Andrew Ross Sorkin in an exclusive interview for The New York Times and CNBC.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Biden Administration Announces Plan to Spend Billions to Prevent Wildfires
description: The plan is an expensive one, but it is only partially funded.
content: After a year that included one of the largest wildfires in California history and ended with an unseasonably late blaze that became the most destructive ever seen in Colorado, the Biden administration on Tuesday announced a 10-year, multibillion-dollar plan to reduce the fire risk on up to 50 million acres that border vulnerable communities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Biden Can Still Rescue His Presidency
description: He needs to remember why the American people elected him.
content: The view that the Biden presidency is flailing — and failing — has now moved from the opinion pages to the news pages, from right-wing criticism to Beltway conventional wisdom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘This Beautiful Future’ Review: Love Glows in War’s Shadow
description: Theaterlab stages a gimlet-eyed romance involving a girl and a young Nazi soldier in Occupied France by the playwright Rita Kalnejais.
content: In the tiny lobby of Theaterlab, on West 36th Street, you need to show proof of a booster vaccine before you can get your tickets. You have to wear a high-grade mask, too, though if you show up unequipped, the person at the box office will cheerfully hand one over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: How Microsoft Bought Activision Blizzard
description: The blockbuster deal for the video game maker came together quickly and opportunistically.
content: Microsoft’s $68.7 billion deal to buy Activision Blizzard is a blockbuster bid to transform the tech giant’s present and its future. If completed, it would be Microsoft’s largest-ever deal and the biggest all-cash acquisition in history. For such a momentous deal, it came together relatively quickly, we can report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcela Valdes
title: Trump’s Dream of a Border Wall, Twisted Into a Sci-Fi Nightmare
description: What inspired a teenager’s baffling pitch for a “wall of drones?”
content: Sometime around 2018, a teenager in a blazer and bluejeans stood in desert scrubland near Las Vegas and made a pitch for U.S. Customs and Border Protection to use an army of drones equipped with electroshock weapons. These drones, he explains in a short video recently unearthed by The Intercept, could help monitor the U.S.-Mexico border. Agents could use the drones to interrogate unauthorized travelers from a distance and to incapacitate subjects who refused to comply with their demands. “There’s no wall here,” the teenager says, “and it probably wouldn’t work anyway, because of the rough terrain and eminent-domain issues. But there is a solution.” He calls it “the wall of drones.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Amazon unveils the title for its big-budget ‘Lord of the Rings’ streaming series.
description: The series, “The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power,” will take place thousands of years before the events of the “Lord of the Rings” trilogy.
content: Amazon Prime Video’s long-gestating “Lord of the Rings” series, which will make its debut on the streaming platform in September, officially has a name: “The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Facebook’s Unglamorous Mistakes
description: Facebook’s little mistakes have big consequences, too. (But only for us.)
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day:‘In a First, Man Receives a Heart From a Genetically Altered Pig’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about this groundbreaking medical procedure and consider its place within the great medical advancements in history.
content: Featured Article: “In a First, Man Receives a Heart From a Genetically Altered Pig” by Roni Caryn Rabin
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Jon Bernthal’s Guide to Making It as a Supporting Actor
description: Not being No. 1 on the call sheet has worked out pretty well for the “King Richard” cast member, who helped power that film to a SAG nomination.
content: For Jon Bernthal, the purest kind of acting happens as part of an ensemble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Weekly Accessible Learning Activities: Spices, Generosity and Words for 2022
description: Each week we spotlight five student activities created for a broad range of learners based on reporting in The New York Times.
content: Each Wednesday we shine a spotlight on five student activities that support a broad range of learners. In this week’s roundup of accessible activities, we invite students to investigate where spices come from, share a story about a moment of generosity, choose a word to set the tone of their life in 2022, look at the winners of our Coming of Age contest, and watch a short film about a colorful character in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Starbucks ends its plan to require worker vaccination and testing.
description: The coffee company is among the first major employers to roll back plans after the Supreme Court blocked the Biden administration’s mandate for large businesses.
content: The Supreme Court’s ruling last week shutting down the Biden administration’s effort to enlist large employers in its vaccination campaign, experts said, would trigger a new wave of uncertainty about how companies keep workers safe from Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Aoife O’Donovan’s Songs Poured Out When Touring Shut Down
description: The singer-songwriter’s third solo album, “Age of Apathy,” is filled with personal touchstones and musical surprises.
content: “I still, to this day, don’t even really think of myself as a songwriter,” Aoife O’Donovan said in a video interview from her home in Orlando. In conversation, as in her songs, her voice often carried a tune, with bursts of syncopation as she explored an idea or a feeling. “I think of myself as a band person, someone you can call to be in your band or play a show. It’s an identity crisis,” she added with a laugh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Mashberg
title: Manhattan Prosecutors Return Two Artifacts to Iraq
description: The repatriations are among the first under Alvin Bragg, the new Manhattan district attorney, who is continuing the work of a dedicated antiquities trafficking unit created by his predecessor.
content: The Manhattan district attorney’s office has returned to Iraq two objects that they seized from the billionaire financier Michael H. Steinhardt and which the officials said were looted during periods of war and unrest there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: It’s Not Complicated. Microsoft Wants Activision for Its Games.
description: Activision has a lot of popular games that fit into Microsoft’s plans to build a vast library of titles that can be played on all sorts of devices. The metaverse can wait.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — It is inevitable now that when a big tech company makes a significant, strategic decision — like Microsoft’s plan to spend $70 billion on the video game giant Activision Blizzard — it invokes the metaverse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Silvio Berlusconi Angles for Italy’s Presidency, Bunga Bunga and All
description: The billionaire former prime minister is working hard to persuade lawmakers to vote for him next week, despite an unusual résumé for a job resting on moral authority.
content: ROME — Early this month, Silvio Berlusconi sat at a dining room table in his mansion with his girlfriend, more than a half-century younger, and an old political ally. As they feasted on a pumpkin souffle and truffle tagliatelle, the 85-year-old Italian former prime minister and billionaire made hours of phone calls, working his way down a list of disaffected lawmakers he hoped to persuade to elect him president of Italy next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: Is It Better to Exercise in the Morning or Evening?
description: Working out at different times of the day might have unique benefits for health, an ambitious new study in mice suggests.
content: Morning exercise has very different effects on metabolism than the same workout later in the day, according to an ambitious new animal study of exercise timing. The study, which involved healthy lab mice jogging on tiny treadmills, mapped hundreds of disparities in the numbers and activities of molecules and genes throughout the rodents’ bodies, depending on whether they ran first thing in the morning or deeper in the evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Syrian Doctor Accused of Atrocities Goes on Trial in Germany
description: The charges against Alaa Mousa include torturing opponents of the Assad regime in military hospitals in Syria, and murdering at least one by lethal injection.
content: The Syrian doctor tortured detainees — opponents of Syria’s president, Bashar al-Assad — by beating them with sticks and kicking them, and even set one on fire, German prosecutors say. In one instance, they allege, he killed a prisoner with a lethal injection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Oil markets are expected to tighten as prices keep rising.
description: The International Energy Agency said demand for oil this year was likely to be higher than expected. Prices are already nearing $90 a barrel.
content: The global oil market is tightening and demand for 2022 is likely to be higher than expected and supply lower than forecast, the International Energy Agency said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Smithsonian Names New Leader of National Museum of the American Indian
description: Cynthia Chavez Lamar, an acting associate director, will be director of the museum, which has one of the largest collections of Native and Indigenous items in the world.
content: The Smithsonian Institution has named Cynthia Chavez Lamar as the new director of the National Museum of the American Indian.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Omicron Is in Retreat
description: What’s next?
content: The latest Omicron developments continue to be encouraging. New Covid-19 cases are plummeting in a growing list of places. The percentage of cases causing severe illness is much lower than it was with the Delta variant. And vaccines — particularly after a booster shot — remain extremely effective in preventing hospitalization and death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk
title: Belgium Convicts 18 in People-Smuggling Case Tied to U.K. Truck Deaths
description: A Belgian court convicted a man said to have been the leader of a human trafficking operation that resulted in the deaths of 39 Vietnamese migrants in 2019. More than a dozen others were also found guilty.
content: BRUSSELS — A court in Belgium found a 45-year-old Vietnamese man guilty of people smuggling, alongside more than a dozen associates, in connection with the deaths of 39 Vietnamese migrants whose bodies were discovered in a truck in Britain, the court’s spokesman said in a statement on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Citing Stand-Your-Ground Law, D.A. Won’t File Charges in Kansas Teen’s Death
description: Cedric Lofton, 17, was handcuffed and placed face down at a detention center in Wichita, Kan., last year. The district attorney says the employees were acting in self-defense.
content: No criminal charges will be filed in the death of Cedric Lofton, a 17-year-old who lost consciousness after he was handcuffed and placed face down in a juvenile detention center in Wichita, Kan., the local district attorney said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Dana Goldstein
title: Answers to Your Questions About School and the Pandemic
description: Dana Goldstein, a Times education reporter, weighs in on questions that she hears frequently from parents.
content: I’m Dana Goldstein, and for two exhausting and contentious years, I’ve covered K-12 education through the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: Does the Supreme Court Need More Justices?
description: The cases for and against altering the court.
content: 2022 is a big year for supporters of Supreme Court reform. Roe v. Wade, the landmark case that gave women nationwide the right to have abortions, might be overturned, and the debate around changing the way we structure the bench — in particular, packing the court — is getting only more heated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost and James Glanz
title: With a Repair Ship Many Days Away, Tonga Faces Weeks of Digital Darkness
description: After a huge volcanic eruption severed the island country’s lone connection to the global internet, a difficult repair job, delving deep into the ocean, lies ahead.
content: As in many remote Pacific nations, the island kingdom of Tonga is connected to the world by a single cable, roughly the width of a garden hose, that carries hair-thin optic fibers across a vast ocean bed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Procter & Gamble’s sales jump as consumers brush off rising prices.
description: The consumer goods giant said it will increase prices on fabric care products in February and personal care products in April.
content: Shoppers shrugged off rising prices last year on products like Pampers diapers and Charmin toilet paper, Procter & Gamble said on Wednesday in announcing a jump in its second-quarter earnings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: A Florida public health official is put on leave after emailing his staff to urge vaccination.
description: Dr. Raul Pino, the state public health administrator in Orlando, told employees that without a good reason, not being vaccinated against the coronavirus was irresponsible.
content: Florida’s top public health official in Orlando has been placed on administrative leave after sending an email to his employees noting their lackluster coronavirus vaccination rates and urging them to get the shots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azeen Ghorayshi
title: Why Are Men More Likely to Die of Covid? It’s Complicated.
description: Sex differences in Covid death rates vary widely from state to state, suggesting they are rooted in behavior as well as biology.
content: It’s one of the most well-known takeaways of the pandemic: Men die of Covid-19 more often than women do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Roberts, Sotomayor and Gorsuch Address Reports of Conflicts Over Masks
description: Justice Sonia Sotomayor, who has diabetes, has been participating in Supreme Court arguments remotely. Justice Neil M. Gorsuch, her seatmate, is the only member of the court who does not wear a mask.
content: WASHINGTON — In an unusual joint statement on Wednesday, Justices Sonia Sotomayor and Neil M. Gorsuch sought to rebut reports that Justice Gorsuch’s refusal to wear a mask at Supreme Court arguments has created tensions between them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Chicago Public Media is set to acquire The Chicago Sun-Times.
description: In an unlikely media deal, the big-city tabloid would become a subsidiary of the nonprofit organization that brings listeners “Wait Wait … Don’t Tell Me.”
content: The hard-hitting tone of tabloid journalism and the measured voice of public radio make for an unlikely combination, but the two are coming together in a novel media deal that is likely to shape how news is covered in Chicago for years to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins
title: When My Mom Got Covid, I Went Searching for Pfizer’s Pills
description: The experience showed how hard it is for many people to get potentially lifesaving treatments.
content: Just after 1 p.m. on Tuesday last week, my phone buzzed with a text message from my mother: “Well, came down with cold, aches, cough etc over wknd.” She had taken an at-home coronavirus test. It was positive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Conrad Ricamora on His Bumpy Road to ‘Little Shop of Horrors’
description: The actor reflects on continuing the Off Broadway revival’s hot streak, and fighting against the stereotypes facing Asian American actors.
content: Since it opened in October 2019, Michael Mayer’s well-received “Little Shop of Horrors” revival has drawn quite the handsome string of leading men: Jonathan Groff was the first to step into Seymour Krelborn’s Converse sneakers, and he was followed by Gideon Glick and Jeremy Jordan. This reflects the casting evolution of the character, a painfully shy plant geek. Not many roles have been played by both Rick Moranis (in the show’s 1986 movie adaptation) and Jake Gyllenhaal (in a 2015 concert production).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Casey and José Bautista
title: Undeterred by Omicron, Tourists Seek Sun in a Welcoming Spain
description: For decades, Spain has been a prime destination for European snowbirds. Even as the Omicron variant spreads, the country is keeping its doors wide open to visitors.
content: TAHICHE, Spain — Coronavirus infections were soaring in Spain, causing caseloads previously unseen in the pandemic. Intensive care unit beds were filling up in hospitals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Enrich
title: They Made the Most of the Opioid Crisis. Until They Didn’t.
description: In “The Hard Sell,” the journalist Evan Hughes tells the story of the rise and fall of Insys Therapeutics — and the larger pharmaceutical industry.
content: THE HARD SELL Crime and Punishment at an Opioid StartupBy Evan Hughes
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz and Mitra Taj
title: In Peru, Courts ‘Used Like Whips’ to Silence Journalists
description: The author of a book about a powerful politician has been sentenced to two years in prison. Media advocates say the case is part of a trend in which the courts are being used to punish critics.
content: The police raided a reporter’s house after he investigated an elite Catholic society. A court ordered journalists’ assets frozen following a defamation complaint from a powerful figure. A sports journalist called the head of a soccer club inept, and was sentenced to a year in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below, along with some solving tips and tricks by Wordplay’s own Deb Amlen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucy King and Jonah M. Kessel
title: We Know the Real Cause of the Crisis in Our Hospitals. It’s Greed.
description: Nurses would like to set the record straight on the hospital staffing crisis.
content: We’re entering our third year of Covid, and America’s nurses — who we celebrated as heroes during the early days of lockdown — are now leaving the bedside. The pandemic arrived with many people having great hope for reform on many fronts, including the nursing industry, but much of that optimism seems to have faded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lia Picard
title: For Some, the Pandemic Has Helped Them Find Their Style
description: Sweatpants? What sweatpants?
content: The phrase “crop top” was not in Laken Brooks’s vocabulary before March 2020. Months of working from home at the start of the pandemic, though, gave the 27-year-old Ph.D. candidate a chance to re-evaluate her fashion choices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill P. Capuzzo
title: Dunellen, N.J.: Affordability, With a ‘Small-Town Quaintness’
description: The Middlesex County borough offers a sense of community and a diversity that feels ‘like being in Brooklyn.’ But the housing market is ‘very tight.’
content: When Dean Mehmood decided it was time to move his family out of Brooklyn, where his parents had been renting for 35 years, he took them on a driving tour of central New Jersey, looking for a place that was affordable and welcoming. He found it in the one-square-mile borough of Dunellen, in Middlesex County.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Officer Shot in Leg in Confrontation With Teen in the Bronx, Police Say
description: Officials said a bullet fired by the suspect struck both him and the officer in what Mayor Eric Adams called another “unacceptable” example of gun violence in New York.
content: A single bullet fired by an armed teenager struck a police officer and the gunman as they scuffled during a confrontation in the Bronx late Tuesday, officials said. Both were expected to recover from their injuries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: In Voting Rights Fight, Democrats Train Ire on Sinema and Manchin
description: Prominent Democrats are expressing rage at their party’s two filibuster holdouts, rather than at Republicans who have blocked their voting rights bill.
content: WASHINGTON — This past Martin Luther King Jr. Day, with a fight for voting rights again at the center of the political agenda, one quotation from the slain civil rights leader’s vast repertoire dominated liberals’ calls to action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Florence Is Burning
description: Inspired by American drag ball culture, the young Finnish designer Ervin Latimer staged a raucous, gender-ambivalent throwdown for his Pitti Uomo debut.
content: FLORENCE, Italy — Radical queer energy is eternal. For millenniums it has endured suppression, oppression, legal, religious and moral sanction, torture, witch hunts, pogroms, a holocaust, caricature and stereotype and several plagues. Yet it survives and thrives in all its subversive glory, surfacing in the most unlikely of places.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: ‘It’s All Just Wild’: Tech Start-Ups Reach a New Peak of Froth
description: There’s more money and more bubbly behavior. Investors insist it’s rational.
content: How crazy is the money sloshing around in start-up land right now?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Are there any off-season travel deals left, or has the pandemic undermined them all?
description: Last February, I searched for a vacation rental in Door County, the wayward spear of Wisconsin that juts into Lake Michigan, for an early May getaway, confident that I had beaten the summer rush to the popular vacation spot. But Airbnb occupancy calendars for lovely converted farmhouses and log cabins were already full.
content: Last February, I searched for a vacation rental in Door County, the wayward spear of Wisconsin that juts into Lake Michigan, for an early May getaway, confident that I had beaten the summer rush to the popular vacation spot. But Airbnb occupancy calendars for lovely converted farmhouses and log cabins were already full.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Cuomo Has $16 Million in Campaign Cash and No Campaign. What Now?
description: The former governor still has a big war chest even as he faces large legal bills.
content: Former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York may have resigned in disgrace last year amid accusations of sexual harassment, but he still controls a war chest of more than $16 million, according to records released on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Senate Opens Voting Rights Debate, With Legislative Defeat Looming
description: Democrats’ bid to force through a new bill intended to offset state voting restrictions appeared doomed to fall to a Republican filibuster.
content: WASHINGTON — Democrats pushed forward on Tuesday with what appeared to be a futile bid to enact voting rights protections over Republican opposition, taking up legislation that they said was urgently needed to counter widespread balloting suppression efforts and laying out a plan to try to steer it around G.O.P. obstruction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Day
title: Britney Spears Fights Father’s Fee Claim, Alleging Financial Misconduct
description: Jamie Spears, suspended as his daughter’s conservator, wants her to pay his legal costs. A filing by her lawyer outlined accusations against him.
content: A lawyer for Britney Spears, in an effort to thwart her father’s demand that she pay his legal bills, claimed in court papers filed on Tuesday that her father and others involved with her conservatorship had committed myriad financial improprieties over several years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Jon Stewart to Receive Mark Twain Prize for American Humor
description: The comedian and former host of “The Daily Show” will receive the Kennedy Center’s annual comedy honor at a ceremony in April.
content: Jon Stewart may no longer be a nightly presence in Americans’ living rooms, but he’s stayed busy directing a film, joining Twitter, making cameos on his friend Stephen Colbert’s “Late Show,” debuting his own, and now, winning a comedy prize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan
title: The Fish That Comes With a Year of Good Luck
description: A Hawaiian specialty cooked the way a local has been making it for 25 years.
content: In Hawaii, I grew up on a street named after a fish — ulua, the biggest of the jacks, a blunt-headed silver bruiser, sometimes weighing more than a hundred pounds, that glowers along the reef. It is caught with tall poles anchored in the sea cliffs and baited with eels or octopus sewed to the hooks. Mahimahi, a neon blur in the deep, was the next street over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Woo and Kellen Browning
title: ‘New Eyes’: Gamers Greet Microsoft’s Activision Deal With Guarded Optimism
description: Some players, unhappy with Activision in recent years, said the Microsoft deal could reverse a decline in quality.
content: When Drew Bienusa began playing Call of Duty, a first-person shooter game published by Activision Blizzard, he was immediately smitten. He loved how immersive having a digital avatar was, and the game was a favorite among his friends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Theodore Roosevelt Statue Removal Begins at Museum of Natural History
description: The equestrian monument to Roosevelt, which has stirred protests as a symbol of colonialism and racism, is leaving its plinth, in pieces.
content: It was past midnight when a crane descended on the imposing bronze statue of Theodore Roosevelt, lifting his upper body from the pedestal where it has presided at the American Museum of Natural History since 1940. The remainder of the sculpture, now surrounded by scaffolding, is scheduled to leave in pieces through the week. Flanked by representations of a Native American man and an African man on foot, the shadow of the president on horseback is diminishing by the day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Your Tech
description: What are your favorite apps and tech tools right now?
content: What tech tools are you finding most fun and useful right now, whether you access them for school, for work or for entertainment? What apps are your current favorites? Why?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly E. Reynolds
title: What Mitt Romney Doesn’t Understand About the End of the Filibuster
description: A Senate without the filibuster would be different, but majority parties would still sometimes have difficulty legislating.
content: If Democrats ever eliminate the filibuster, would it change the Senate and inject chaos into the workings of the government? Last week, Senator Mitt Romney of Utah raised that prospect, saying that without the filibuster, “whenever one party replaced the other as majority, tax and spending priorities would change, safety net programs would change, national security policy could change.” This is a common argument against ditching the filibuster and its minimum 60-vote requirement to end debate on most legislation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Hoberman
title: France’s Colonial Conflict, Filmed From Both Sides
description: “The Olive Trees of Justice,” a neorealist take on the Algerian War made with nonprofessional actors, is newly restored and still resonates today.
content: Shot in Algeria on the eve of independence, “The Olive Trees of Justice” is the only fiction film by the American documentarian James Blue and, based on a novel by the French Algerian writer Jean Pélégri, one that acknowledges colonial oppression as well as post-colonial displacement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: In Rebuke to Trump, Supreme Court Allows Release of Jan. 6 Files
description: The House committee investigating the riot received hundreds of pages of documents from the former president’s White House within hours of the ruling.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday refused a request from former President Donald J. Trump to block the release of White House records concerning the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, effectively rejecting Mr. Trump’s claim of executive privilege and clearing the way for the House committee investigating the riot to receive the documents hours later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Opinion
title: Quitters, We Want to Hear From You!
description: Tell us what it’s like to be part of the Great Resignation.
content: We know a little bit about what’s happened within the American work force over the past unprecedented year. We know that over the course of 2021, almost 40 million workers left a job. We know that some of them are using this time to take a break and re-evaluate what they want from work. We know that some haven’t so much quit as felt forced out by the various unyielding needs of life during a pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Your Kid’s Existential Dread Is Normal
description: It’s part of growing up, even if it’s pandemic-tinged.
content: My 9-year-old daughter’s existential crises hit at night. About once a month, she’ll wander into our room after bedtime full of unanswerable questions about her own place in the universe. “Why are we even here?” she’ll ask us. And this tends to happen after 10 p.m. on a weeknight, when her dad and I are least capable of giving her a vaguely satisfying answer. It’s a genuine reflection of the way her mind works, even if it’s also a bedtime stalling tactic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaux Laskey
title: 11 One-Pot Winner-Winner Chicken Dinners
description: Because no one needs more dishes to wash.
content: For many of us, getting a home-cooked dinner on the table after a long day is a tiny miracle, so choosing a dish that doesn’t require a lot of clean-up is especially important. These 11 one-pot (or -pan) chicken dishes are here to save you from the sink. Full disclosure: Some of these recipes require an additional bowl or two for prep, but the complete meal is finished in a single vessel, so you can serve right from the stove. Since we know many of you will ask, yes, several of the recipes that call for bone-in chicken can be made with boneless chicken thighs or breasts: Just reduce your cook time accordingly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Williams
title: Thoreau, Emerson and the Town Where Their Thoughts Took Root
description: “The Transcendentalists and Their World,” by Robert A. Gross, focuses on Concord, Mass.
content: THE TRANSCENDENTALISTS AND THEIR WORLDBy Robert A. Gross
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winston Choi-Schagrin
title: New Research Shows How Health Risks to Children Mount as Temperatures Rise
description: The first nationwide study on rising temperatures and younger Americans found that hotter days were associated with more visits to emergency rooms.
content: Hotter temperatures in late spring and summer were associated with higher rates of emergency-room visits for children across the United States, researchers said Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: A Los Angeles Vaccine Clinic Overcomes Mistrust Skeptic by Skeptic
description: The staff at a vaccination site in Watts has spent seven months trying to turn the tide of vaccine hesitancy.
content: LOS ANGELES — Two million. That’s the number of unvaccinated people in Los Angeles County — more than three times the population of Wyoming, and a commentary on the sheer scale of the county, the nation’s most populous by far. It’s also an indicator on how vulnerable Los Angeles remains to the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse, Jonathan Weisman and Catie Edmondson
title: Republicans block action on voting rights legislation again, setting the stage for a filibuster showdown.
description: Republicans used the filibuster for a fifth time to block action on the bill, and Democrats pledged to begin what appeared to be a doomed bid to change Senate rules to pass it.
content: Senate Republicans on Wednesday blocked action on Democrats’ far-reaching federal voting rights protections, thwarting a key piece of President Biden’s agenda after senators sparred during a rare, often fierce, all-day debate about access to the ballot box and the integrity of the filibuster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: Yvette Mimieux, Who Found Fame With ‘The Time Machine,’ Dies at 80
description: Playing fragile characters, she had success in the 1960s in “Where the Boys Are” and other movies before her acting career took a downturn.
content: Yvette Mimieux, who found stardom in the early 1960s portraying delicate, fragile women in “The Time Machine,” “Where the Boys Are” and other films, died on Monday night at her home in Los Angeles. She was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Why Millions Think It Is Trump Who Cannot Tell a Lie
description: “What perhaps looks like collective derangement to many outside the party ranks is really just raw political calculation.”
content: Why is Donald Trump’s big lie so hard to discredit?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Lola Fadulu
title: New Government Website for Ordering Covid Tests Is Up and Running
description: Visitors can go to covidtests.gov and click through to a Postal Service web page where they can order four tests per household, free of charge.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration’s new website allowing people to order up to four free at-home coronavirus tests quietly went live on Tuesday — a day in advance of its formal launch — and demand already appeared to be significant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Precious Fondren
title: Teenager Sentenced to 14 Years to Life in Tessa Majors Murder
description: The final chapter in the stabbing of Ms. Majors, a Barnard College student, was closed on Wednesday as the last of her attackers was sentenced in Manhattan.
content: A little more than two years after the brutal murder of Tessa Majors, an 18-year-old Barnard College student, the last teenager to be sentenced in her killing received 14 years to life in prison on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser and Michael Christopher Brown
title: Sifting Through the Train Thefts of Los Angeles
description: A Union Pacific rail hub is strewn with the castoffs from goods looted from train cars that dip below street level. The company put losses, claims and damages at about $5 million.
content: The railroad tracks are a wasteland of discarded cartons, envelopes and boxes. Pieces of clothing lie disgorged from packaging and tossed aside. A family photograph, propped up in the garbage, stands sentimental to someone, somewhere, but of no interest to those who loot the tracks of Lincoln Heights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage, Eric Schmitt, Azmat Khan, Evan Hill and Christoph Koettl
title: Newly Declassified Video Shows U.S. Killing of 10 Civilians in Drone Strike
description: The New York Times obtained footage of the botched strike in Kabul, whose victims included seven children, through a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit.
content: WASHINGTON — Newly declassified surveillance footage provides additional insights about the final minutes and aftermath of a botched U.S. drone strike last year in Kabul, Afghanistan,  showing how the military made a life-or-death decision based on imagery that was fuzzy, hard to interpret in real time and prone to confirmation bias.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: What Are Your Thoughts About Hunting Animals?
description: Is hunting a hobby you have pursued or something you would like to try? If your school offered a supervised hunting experience, would you participate?
content: Have you ever gone hunting? If so, what were you hunting? What was the experience like? If you’ve never gone hunting, would you like to? Why or why not?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: Can Omicron Cause Long Covid?
description: It is too soon to know, scientists say, but mild initial illness may not signal reduced risk.
content: Many public health officials have taken heart in early evidence that suggests infections from the Omicron variant tend to cause less severe illness than other versions of the coronavirus. But another important question looms: whether infection with Omicron, including breakthrough cases in vaccinated people, can result in long Covid — the constellation of physical, neurological and cognitive symptoms that can last for months and impair people’s daily lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: The Upside of Anxiety
description: There are several benefits to having an internal alarm system, experts say.
content: For the entirety of my adult life I have tried to avoid driving.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, Ben Protess and William K. Rashbaum
title: N.Y. Attorney General Outlines Pattern of Possible Fraud at Trump Business
description: The attorney general, Letitia James, released new details of her investigation as she argued for the need to question Donald J. Trump and two of his children under oath.
content: The New York State attorney general, Letitia James, accused Donald J. Trump’s family business late Tuesday of repeatedly misrepresenting the value of its assets to bolster its bottom line, saying in court papers that the company had engaged in “fraudulent or misleading” practices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rob Szypko, Jessica Cheung, Stella Tan, Paige Cowett, John Ketchum, Dan Powell and Elisheba Ittoop
title: A Last-Gasp Push on Voting Rights
description: President Biden knows that he cannot pass a set of laws to protect elections. So why is he still asking the Senate to vote on the bills?
content: It’s a big week in the Senate for voting rights. Democrats have bills that include measures to target voter suppression and gerrymandering, and an increase in federal oversight of elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Putin to Ukraine: ‘Marry Me or I’ll Kill You’
description: He’s not particularly concerned, though, with what’s in Ukraine.
content: Why is Vladimir Putin threatening to take another bite out of Ukraine, after devouring Crimea in 2014? That is not an easy question to answer because Putin is a one-man psychodrama, with a giant inferiority complex toward America that leaves him always stalking the world with a chip on his shoulder so big it’s amazing he can fit through any door.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Seems Ready to Back Ted Cruz in Campaign Finance Case
description: Mr. Cruz challenged a federal law that caps repayments of loans from candidates to their campaigns from postelection contributions.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court seemed ready on Wednesday to side with a challenge to a federal campaign finance law brought by Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas, in what would be the latest in a series of decisions dismantling various aspects of campaign finance regulations on First Amendment grounds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: Free At-Home Tests
description: And restaurant critics talk indoor dining.
content: The Biden administration’s website that allows people to order up to four free at-home coronavirus tests quietly went live today — a day in advance of its formal introduction — and demand already appears to be significant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: banish
description: This word has appeared in 50 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden says he will pursue a scaled-back agenda as he defends his first year in office.
description: President Biden reserved his most aggressive language for Republicans in Congress, accusing them of conspiring to block everything that his administration has tried to do.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden vowed on Wednesday to pursue a scaled-back version of his marquee domestic policy plan as he mounted a two-hour defense of his first-year accomplishments and repeatedly blamed Republicans for abandoning any serious attempt to govern the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Gaspard Ulliel, French Actor and ‘Moon Knight’ Star, Dies at 37
description: He gained fame as a young Hannibal Lecter and the designer Yves Saint Laurent. He died after a skiing accident weeks before he is to appear in a Disney+ series.
content: Gaspard Ulliel, a star of French cinema best known outside his native country for portraying the young Hannibal Lecter in “Hannibal Rising” and the fashion designer Yves Saint Laurent in “Saint Laurent,” died on Wednesday, the day after a skiing accident in France. He was 37.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Better.com’s founder returns as C.E.O. after firing 900 workers on Zoom.
description: The company said it had conducted a “thorough, independent” review of its culture.
content: Vishal Garg, the Better.com founder, who fired roughly 900 of his workers via Zoom last month and then took “time off,” is returning to his position as the head of his mortgage lending company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Rawan Sheikh Ahmad
title: Israel Evicts Palestinians in Flashpoint Area of East Jerusalem
description: Israelis evicted an extended family and destroyed their homes in the Sheikh Jarrah neighborhood, where attempted evictions last year helped spark a war with Gaza.
content: JERUSALEM — Israeli police evicted two Palestinian families from their homes on Wednesday to make way for a new school in Sheikh Jarrah, a neighborhood of East Jerusalem where previous attempts to evict other Palestinians stirred tensions that built up to the war last year between Israel and Hamas, the militant Islamist group in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: Françoise Gilot: ‘It Girl’ at 100
description: The painter, writer and the only woman with the spunk and self-determination to leave Picasso has a few things to say about success, personal style and the nature of intimacy.
content: Seated bolt upright on a cream-colored sofa, Françoise Gilot was as grave as an oracle, an impression enhanced by her precision-tailored flame red suit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Britain’s inflation rate climbs to its highest level in 30 years.
description: The consumer price index rose to 5.4 percent in December from a year earlier, adding to concerns about painful months ahead for household budgets.
content: Prices in Britain rose at their fastest pace in 30 years in December, according to the national statistics agency, stoking concerns about the strain on household budgets with inflation still months away from its expected peak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Thursday Briefing: Blinken Visits Ukraine
description: U.S. officials pushed back on Moscow’s negotiation demands.
content: Before a meeting tomorrow with Russia’s foreign minister in Geneva, Secretary of State Antony Blinken said that Russia could attack Ukraine “on very short notice” and warned of “confrontation and consequences for Russia” if it does.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxana Popescu
title: House Hunting in Guatemala: Among Volcanoes in Antigua for $299,000
description: The historic city, a tourist and retirement destination for locals and foreigners alike, is seeing an influx of buyers who can work remotely.
content: This two-bedroom townhouse sits in a gated community on the outskirts of Antigua, the colonial city and UNESCO Heritage Site surrounded by volcanoes in the highlands of central Guatemala, about 25 miles west of Guatemala City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: A Trove of Old Photos Could Reveal the Future of These Arctic Glaciers
description: The Svalbard Islands, part of Norway, are warming seven times faster than the global average. Aerial pictures from the 1930s are helping researchers understand what that means for the region’s ice.
content: The mammoth, ethereally beautiful glaciers of the Norwegian archipelago of Svalbard, near the North Pole, bear the scars of climate change more than almost anywhere else on the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: Kathy Griffin Is Trying to Get Back on the D-List
description: Ever since her Trump joke went wrong in 2017, Griffin has been seeking a professional rebirth, and wondering who among the canceled gets a second chance.
content: When Kathy Griffin met last summer with a surgeon to discuss the removal of the upper lobe of her left lung, and the cancer in it, she got right to the point. “Can this wait?” she asked. “Because I’ve got a gig.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Gold
title: A Possible Sex Offender Doesn’t Look Good on a Commemorative Tea Towel
description: The royal family is a business, and Prince Andrew had become a liability.
content: PENZANCE, England — Prince Andrew is in internal exile in Windsor, 20 miles west of London. Last week a judge in Manhattan ruled that a lawsuit brought by Virginia Giuffre, a woman who accused Andrew of sexually assaulting her in 2001, when she was 17 and was, she said, trafficked by Jeffrey Epstein, could proceed. (Andrew has denied the accusations.) A day later, Buckingham Palace issued a statement effectively banishing him from royal life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Talks between Russia and the U.S.
content: Seeking to head off a potential assault on Ukraine, Antony Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, will meet with Sergey Lavrov, Russia’s foreign minister, in Geneva on Friday as the two sides explore whether there is still a diplomatic path to avoiding a conflict in Eastern Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Theaters and museums open as salons and gyms for a day in protest over a Dutch lockdown.
description: The country’s Covid measures were eased last week, but many arts venues had to remain closed and many in the sector are unhappy about it.
content: Dozens of theaters and museums in the Netherlands planned to open as hair salons and gyms on Wednesday in what was billed as a playful protest over a continued nationwide lockdown in the arts sector even as restrictions on some businesses were reduced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Everyone Is Quitting.Here’s the Right Way to Do It.
description: From understanding why you want to leave to tackling health insurance and retirement plans, here’s your guide to a graceful exit — without leaving money on the table.
content: Everyone, sometime or another, dreams of quitting. For millions, the fantasy is real.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What We Know About the Tonga Volcano
description: The explosion probably won’t cool the planet as some previous eruptions have done, but its effects could be felt around the world in other ways.
content: When the Hunga volcano in the Pacific island nation of Tonga erupted with a huge explosion on Saturday, climate scientists took notice. Eruptions emit sulfur dioxide gas, and if enough of it is shot high enough into the atmosphere, it can have a cooling effect on the Earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes and Sabrina Imbler
title: In Sewage, Clues to Omicron’s Surge
description: Tracking the virus in wastewater is helping some cities and hospitals respond to the most recent wave of the coronavirus, but a more coordinated national effort is needed, experts say.
content: As the highly contagious Omicron variant pushes national coronavirus case numbers to record highs and sends hospitals across the country into crisis mode, public health officials are eagerly searching for an indication of how long this surge might last.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian Kimble
title: How Marshawn Lynch Became an N.F.L. Mentor
description: The former Super Bowl champion has always had a way with words. It has turned him into a trusted adviser to N.F.L. and college football players who want to use their “wittys to get up out that siti.”
content: Marshawn Lynch absolutely refuses to code switch. His candor, regardless of the audience, has yielded unforgettable quotations — “I’m just here so I won’t get fined”; “Take care of your chicken, take care of your mental” — that have marked him as a sage of sorts, somebody who is sought out in his retirement by current players in need of mentoring and by brands hoping to make an impression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: Free N95 Masks
description: And tracking down Covid pills.
content: The Biden administration announced today that it was making 400 million nonsurgical N95 masks available, free of charge, at community health centers and retail pharmacies across the U.S.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: University of Michigan Will Pay $490 Million to Settle Abuse Cases
description: The accord is among the largest ever agreed to by an American university to compensate victims of sexual abuse.
content: The University of Michigan said Wednesday that it would pay $490 million to more than a thousand people who had accused a doctor who worked with football players and other students of sexual abuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: ‘We’re Basically Mall Cops’: Texas Guard Members on Border Mission
description: Gov. Greg Abbott deployed thousands of Texas National Guard members to the Texas-Mexico border. But soldiers complain of difficulties and a seemingly rudderless mission.
content: McALLEN, Texas — After thousands of migrants crossed into Del Rio, Texas, last year and overwhelmed the authorities, Gov. Greg Abbott ordered thousands of National Guard troops to the border, sharply expanding their role in a mission known as Operation Lone Star.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The 5G Snafu Was Avoidable
description: Government agencies should have worked together to keep the skies safe while introducing new wireless technology.
content: The snafu over 5G cellular service at U.S. airports is unfortunate and unnecessary. From what I can tell, most of the blame falls on a bureaucratic battle between sister agencies, the Federal Aviation Administration and the Federal Communications Commission. Politics trumped economics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sonia Shah and Tyler Comrie
title: Animals Infecting Humans Is Scary. It’s Worse When We Infect Them Back.
description: Mink farms threaten to become a source of new coronavirus variants — and an object lesson in how ‘spillback’ can make deadly diseases even deadlier.
content: A mink farm in northern Utah sat at the end of a narrow, rutted road lined by modest, densely packed ranch houses. The farm consisted of a grassy lot partly enclosed by stakes with wire wrapped haphazardly around them and a small, chain-link swing gate. Long, narrow mink sheds a few yards beyond the gate were so close to the road that I could see inside their dark interiors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Check It Out for Yourself!
description: Ori Brian’s puzzle has a uni-que theme.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Happy Wednesday, solvers! We’ve got a Thursday-ish offering today from Ori Brian, a constructor who is making his seventh appearance in the New York Times Crossword. If you haven’t solved this puzzle yet, be sure to read the note at the top of the interface if you’re solving online. And if you are solving the old-fashioned way, well, you’ll probably notice something a little different today. More on the theme below, but first, some breaking news for competitive solvers and those interested in exploring the competitive-solving scene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $620,000 Homes in Connecticut, Virginia and Alabama
description: A 1788 house in West Simsbury, a three-bedroom rowhouse in Leesburg and a four-bedroom home in Vestavia Hills.
content: In its early years, this house was a stagecoach stop for travelers passing through this part of Connecticut, about 15 miles from Hartford and 30 miles from Springfield, Mass. The house is well preserved, with its original mantels and moldings in several of the main living spaces. It is within walking distance of a small shopping center, a post office and the Tulmeadow Farm Store, a popular spot to buy seasonal produce, baked goods and freshly made ice cream. A number of schools are within a five-minute drive, including public elementary and high schools, a private school for students in kindergarten through 12th grade and an all-girls school for sixth through 12th grades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: I Had Breakthrough Covid. Can I Start Living Like It’s 2019?
description: As Omicron cases skyrocket, more vaccinated people may get “hybrid” immunity after a breakthrough infection. But experts still encourage precautions.
content: Like many New Yorkers, Domenica D’Ottavio contracted Covid-19 over the Christmas holidays. Her head clogged with congestion, her body ached; she coughed and spiked a fever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson and Azi Paybarah
title: Judge Dismisses Wrongful-Death Lawsuit Filed by Whitey Bulger’s Estate
description: The lawsuit, which sought $200 million in damages, contended that prison officials had placed the notorious Boston mob boss in harm’s way when they transferred him to a federal prison where he was beaten to death in 2018.
content: A federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit filed by the administrator of James (Whitey) Bulger’s estate, who had argued that prison officials placed the notorious Boston mob boss in harm’s way when they transferred him to a violent federal prison in West Virginia where he was beaten to death in 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: After Australia, Djokovic is likely to run into problems in France and the U.S.
description: The French authorities say that players must be vaccinated to compete in the French Open, the next of the four Grand Slam tournaments.
content: With Novak Djokovic back in his native Serbia, unable to compete in the Australian Open because he is not vaccinated against the coronavirus, a big question mark looms over what comes next for the world’s top male tennis player.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fred A. Bernstein
title: Ricardo Bofill, Architect of Otherworldly Buildings, Dies at 82
description: His structures were so bold, they were the backdrops for TV shows and films, including “Westworld” and a “Hunger Games” movie. But they were also socially aware.
content: Ricardo Bofill, a Spanish architect behind some of the world’s most startling buildings, died on Friday at a hospital in Barcelona. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘Definition Please’ Review: What Does It All Mean?
description: A grown-up spelling bee star who never left her hometown tries to make sense of the conflicts and challenges in her family.
content: “Definition Please” begins with wee Monica Chowdry winning the Scribbs National Spelling Bee. She claims the title after using up all the time-buying requests allowed, including the one that gives the actor-writer-director Sujata Day’s sincere, Bollywood-winking film its title.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill P. Capuzzo and Claudia Gryvatz Copquin
title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey

title: Emily’s List Threatens to Pull Support From Sinema Over Filibuster Stance
description: The powerful political action committee said the Arizona senator could find herself “standing alone” in 2024 if she refuses to change Senate rules to force through voting rights legislation.
content: WASHINGTON — One of the largest contributors to Senator Kyrsten Sinema’s political rise announced on Tuesday that it would cut off its financial support if the senator continues to refuse to change the Senate’s filibuster rules to allow for passage of far-reaching voting rights legislation.

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Has the Pandemic Undermined Off-Season Deals?
description: In many places, high-occupancy rates are inflating prices for budget-minded travelers who count on off-peak periods to find the best bargains. Here’s what to do and where to look.
content: Last February, I searched for a vacation rental in Door County, the wayward spear of Wisconsin that juts into Lake Michigan, for an early May getaway, confident I had beaten the summer rush to the popular vacation spot. But Airbnb occupancy calendars for lovely converted farmhouses and log cabins were already full and when I called a local vacation home rental agency, the agent said they were almost completely booked through the summer. That’s how I ended up in a one-bedroom shack last spring with a wobbly card table in an ant-infested kitchen and a new awareness of the shrinking off-season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: In ‘Last Resort,’ a Writer Turns a Friend’s Story Into a Smash Success
description: Andrew Lipstein’s entertaining debut novel mines comedy from an aspiring author’s ethically questionable path to publication.
content: Cowardly, avaricious, annoying, territorial, deceitful, opportunistic: There aren’t enough shady adjectives in the dictionary to describe the narrator of Andrew Lipstein’s “Last Resort.” What fun! One great thing about the well-drawn weasels of fiction is that you can always locate a bit of yourself in them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: How Being Sick Changed My Health Care Views
description: A chronic illness made me more left-wing and more libertarian at once.
content: Often around the turn of the year I perform an act of pundit accountability, looking back on the previous year’s columns to assess the things that I got wrong. For this January’s edition, though, I’m going to take a different kind of backward glance, and try to answer one of the frequent questions I received when I wrote, last fall, about my experience with chronic illness: Namely, has being sick altered any of my views on health care policy?

content: Sara McLanahan, a Princeton sociologist whose landmark studies of households led by one parent — much of which suggested poorer outcomes for children born to single mothers — laid the groundwork for research into the changing structure of the American family, died on Dec. 31 at her home in Manhattan. She was 81.

Still, I headed out the door, because my last call of the day had been with a couple of professional runners, each with multiple national championship titles in distance running under their belt.
